for adopting AWS this this presentation really is to give you some feelers for
how we go about building business cases with our customers when they start the journey to AWS so when the begin we're

off the types of business case that we typically see our customers building and how much information they actually need

business case is really going to sell the concept of cloud in your organization and we often find with our
customers that there are those people in the organization are already sold on cloud who just want to get on with it and do that but then you have to
actually give the organization reasons to move to cloud and we heard earlier from some of our speakers talking about

organizational risk is another key benefit of of adopting the cloud as well so we look at the sort of value benefits
that sit around adopting cloud alongside the the financial business case as well
so what does a business case really tell us well first of all it's going to let us know what the cost of getting into
AWS is going to be so you're currently running in a state of servers in four or five data centers you're gonna have a
fairly good idea of what that's costing you today we will need to be able to know what it's going to take to migrate
those workloads into AWS and and land in a in a deployment in AWS we also want to
know what it costs to stay in AWS so what's the operating cost once you've landed what other benefits the business

you know those sorts of benefits and what are the costs of keeping application workloads where they are
compared to AWS so doing nothing to actually doing something with AWS and we
look we do that comparison because it's important to say well if you do nothing if you don't modernize if you if you don't make these changes in the
organization then you start to see increases in risk you start to see an opportunities where your application
workloads on-premise they're gonna perhaps misbehave and and not be able to continue the journey that you plan for
them in the long term so types of business case we typically see it's
really a starting business case which is directional so our customers tend to be at the directional end plus or minus 30%
accurate so a custom we'll be very happy to say you know this is a business case where I'm currently paying ninety million pounds a year for my data center of
state it's a standard charge back model to my parent group and I want to move to the cloud oh and it's gonna cost 24
million pounds a year to do that same thing in a dress that's a pretty compelling business case so you tend not to need to do anything more in terms of

inaccurate if you've got those sorts of numbers however you'd you also need to drill down and do a detailed business
case if you don't have that kind of knowledge about your estate so what we tend to find is that customers move

rack just a single data center and there's a presentation a very simple Excel output so in a really really

in professional services take maybe four to ten weeks and the reason for that is we're doing very very high fidelity data
analysis we're looking at servers and components and applications and memory consumption and we're looking at things

are customer obsessed we want to make sure that we produce that in this case that the customer needs and actually

you've done it in one or two days it's just disappointing really that you can't do the detailed version so when do you
build a business case well and you may have seen this chart before this is our stages of adoption and I know Thomas
talked about stage of adoption in his keynote but we have a concept here where our customers
typically are in one of four stages of adoption of the cloud first stage is project and that's typically where
they're being proof of concepts or development workloads into the cloud they're just trying the cloud for the first time getting a feel for what it
can do for the organization then we have the foundational stage and this is where we start to hook up internal business
systems internal IT to the cloud a hybrid model where we are running production in both areas both in the
cloud and in our on-prem data centers and then we hit the migration stage which is really where we start to make a
commitment to a fast-paced scaled out migration to the cloud we know we're moving tens of thousands of
servers potentially out to AWS and once we've landed in the cloud we then start
to see very very accelerated retirement of technical debt and we start to see clouds native apps drop directly into
serval as microcircuits architectures and we reach then a final stage of reinvention which is where we take those
monolithic applications we've moved into AWS onto ec2 our standard compute unit
and we've started to move those into being this service a diverse lamda API gateway type application so we're
reinventing those applications after they've landed so where do we build a business case well actually we do it at
all four stages so it's really really important to realize that each stage is a gating criteria for a business case
you know if you're going to move from ec2 in the migration stage onto a service environment you need to be able
to work out what it's going to cost you to run functions instead of code running on ec2 instances so understanding the
economics of that is is really really key as is the first sort of decision to run a project in in AWS as well so
that's when to build a business case it's as all four stages it's at all points where you're going to be dropping a workload into AWS so let's let's just
take a segue into applied economics and this this chart is something that I've been showing to people and to customers

basis that a typical migration takes around two years so the blue bit in the front there is what we call the
migration bubble and the migration bubble are all of the costs that are associated with getting
your workloads and moving them into AWS or where it's a new workload it's the adoption cost of AWS so actually
building out your landing zones building out your security posture all the things that you need to do to be able to actually get into the cloud also the
migration bubble could be things like training your team's training staff building out that the the types of people that you need in the organization
to be able to execute the migration for you so that's all migration bubble cost and we call that the total cost of my
Gration we then have total cost of ownership and we've often talked about
total cost of ownership as being a business case and it was you know very very often as a former customer where I

in the business case and the answer was will do a TCO and that's all you got was just a TCO and I need to know what it

got with TCO is it it's valid or used to be valid for one hour because that was our smallest billing unit as you now
know we have one second billing okay so TCO becomes a little bit of a
problem because one second billing means that TCO should be the maximum you ever paid to get into AWS for that workload
because you should immediately be following with cost optimization so driving down costs right sizing servers
as you move in but right sizing servers as you're in the cloud as well so being able to do continuous refreshes of
instances being able to do continuous changes of services within a device is part and parcel of using a device and
the ADA breast story so cost optimizing and reducing your cost from that TCO point and and down is really what you
should be doing from day one so the TCO window is literally one second of time
and should be the maximum you pay for that workload after it's landed we also need to be able to extrapolate the

after migration are we gonna see payback are we gonna be spending less in either base than we were on Prem and you tend

two years there's possibly something wrong in the numbers and we need to look at that in more detail so you should be getting a decent payback
period for any workloads you're moving into a diverse and certainly less than two years I would say and finally we

application releases are we doing a week or a day because we've moved to the cloud those those sorts of value benefits need
to be articulate that we need to understand actually what are the value benefits of being in the cloud today a
lot of our customers for example will have disaster recovery estates that sit in their data centers that are not used
will sit there in a warmed up mode waiting for a disaster and one of our bank customers and 17% of their estate
was there just for that in a SS you don't need 17% the server's sat on a rack waiting for a disaster down because
you can architect your applications to work around failover and and and things like easy failures and and fail and you

that's a value benefit of the cloud and the reason I took you on this sort of tour of cloud economics is is that all
